pull.title: net processing: clamp PeerManager::Options user input
pull.body:
Avoid out-of-bounds user input for `PeerManager::Options` by safely clamping `-maxorphantx` and `-blockreconstructionextratxn`, and avoid platform-specific behaviour by changing `PeerManager::Options::max_extra_txs` from `size_t` to a `uint32_t`. Addresses https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/27499#pullrequestreview-1544114932.

Also documents all `PeerManager::Options` members, addressing https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/27499#discussion_r1272302469.

Also changes max_extra_txs into a uint32_t to avoid platform-specific

comments.body:
nit, includes a bit more than replaced and orphans
```suggestion
        //! Number of non-mempool transactions to keep around for block reconstruction. Includes orphan, replaced, and rejected transactions.
```
Wondering if we can come up with a more sane upper limit for both of these?

Given that we use this value [to size a vector](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/e35fb7bc48d360585b80d0c7f89ac5087c1d405e/src/net_processing.cpp#L1654), that could be sensible, but of course, arbitrary upper limits bring their own set of problems. I'll look into it more, thanks!
Let's just leave it as is, was more of a nit anyway

unrelated: May be good to write a clang-tidy plugin to enforce the limits are compile-time constants and in range to avoid silent UB at runtime?

The in-range one can be submitted to upstream and the other check can be done in this repo.

```suggestion
        options.max_orphan_txs = uint32_t(std::clamp<int64_t>(*value, 0, std::numeric_limits<uint32_t>::max()));
```

nit, if you re-touch?
